posts.cooked:
6201 is using the WCP Greyt elevator with very few modifications. The mechanism is driven by a NEO in a 9:1 Maxplanetary.

For whatever reason, when we run the elevator full power up and down, we tend to skip chain during the downward motion.

Video here (elevator up/then down to a mid position/thendown to the bottom) with the section of the video around the chain skipping slowed down to 1/4 speed.

Any thoughts on how we can solve this? The chain is taut already, although I suppose we could make it tighter.

posts.name: R.C.
posts.cooked: Probably want to make sure your back cross bar is secure and not bending. It’ll cause your chain to appear taught but loosen up when load is applied.
Quick response thanks! We’ll check that out tomorrow. Anything else obvious to check if that’s not it?

posts.name: R.C.
posts.cooked:
Overall stiffness/bending is what I always check in a mechanism. We’ve had this happen on the team (1323) on multiple occasions.

2023 → The horizontal elevator wasn’t stiff enough and would ratchet quite a bit. Turns out the structure could just bow in we had to add CF stiffeners and make the mounting more legit on one end.

2025 → Belt would ratchet and had to stiffen up the entire elevator so the end points couldn’t bow inwards due to high acceleration/load.

Elevator top bar seems stiff to me?

Hard to notice any deflection.

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked:
I’d look at chain tension next.

You’re moving quite fast so the acceleration loads will be high.

posts.name: Red Raider Admin
posts.cooked: We swapped to #35 chain and it solved this problem.  You’ll need comparable sprockets.  Let us know if you need any more guidance on that part.  Once we did that, we were able to double our elevator speed just because we weren’t skipping anymore. To be honest, it should probably be #35 chain instead.

posts.name: Atlas
posts.cooked: We’re running a 3-stage greyt elevator with two Neos (total reduction somewhere near 15:1). We had the same issue and made the same change. We’re now using 15 tooth #35 sprockets. The pitch diameter is around 0.04" larger than the 22 tooth 25 sprocket, which was close enough to have minimal impact on the chain line. The larger teeth make all the difference. It’s still possible to make the chain skip if the elevator goes full speed downwards and rapidly changes direction. However, we’ve tuned the control scheme to limit the max acceleration.

@R.C Congrats on the win!

Our tentative plan is to follow the advice of the others in this thread and switch to #35 chain on the elevator.

We were also discussing adding some CF springs to counter balance our carriage as a way to decrease the forces on either end of travel.

Is there any more weight-conscious solution we could try first?
What did you use to attach the #35 chain to the first moving stage?

posts.name: R.C.
posts.cooked:
You can probably try adding a small acceleration and deceleration ramp. If you’re using krakens this is pretty easy to do we do this on our belted elevator as well.

Its hard for me to tell from the video but we didn’t notice this issue on the CC or previous elevators we’ve built. I’ll need to investigate deeper this offseason.

posts.name: Kyle Reeve
posts.cooked: Assuming your GitHub is up to date, it looks like you’re configuring a bunch of max motion stuff but then you’re running the elevator in pure position control? Reefscape-2025/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/Elevator.java at main · TheHighlanders/Reefscape-2025 · GitHub that’ll probably cause some pretty harsh accelerations when you start moving and your error term is large
